title: 'Totally skint' mum starts rude greetings card business with just £30
text:

Pop into your local card shop and you can generally find a healthy selection of risqué cards for any occasion.

But when Stacey Dennis wanted to find a really rude card for a friend with a similar sense of humour, she couldn’t find anything sufficiently crude.

So she decided to start making her own. This was back in 2015, and Stacey had recently been made redundant from a job as a graphic designer.

Four years later and her firm, named LoveLayla , has grown to the point that it is now a multi-million pound operation, having won a legion of celebrity fans.

You won’t get very far with greetings cards

Stacey says that she initially started the firm as a freelance graphic design business, but turned to cards for special occasions after that disappointing shopping experience.

Starting with just £30 from her kitchen table, she admits: “We were totally skint… I didn’t have a clue what I was doing.”

And while family and friends were very supportive, one comment was made that “you’re not going to get very far with greetings cards”.

Keeping up with orders

Thankfully for Stacey and her family, that didn’t turn out to be the most accurate of predictions, with interest in the firm’s range of cheeky cards quickly taking off.

Stacey admits that the big challenge initially was getting the orders out as professionally as possible, often with little sleep.

“It was about keeping on top of the business and not letting it run away.”

A big factor in those early sleepless nights was the fact that Stacey and husband Jay also had one-year-old Layla to worry about, their daughter and inspiration for the business’s name.

Stacey suggests that these long nights were actually something of a blessing in disguise, allowing her to come up with card ideas from a parenting angle.

She adds: “Lots of card ideas come from the frustrating and tiring times,” particularly when it comes to creative use of swear words.

A network of support

LoveLayla was clearly built on a team effort, with Stacey’s parents looking after Layla a few times a week before she started school so that Stacey could devote her time to the burgeoning business.

Her friend Vikki also helped with childcare and now works in the business.

“In the early days, my family and friends all helped us to pack the cards and stick stamps and address labels.

"In the evenings, food parcels were brought for us when we were dead on our feet and my husband and business partner Jay used to stay up every night to manage all the paperwork and orders while I fed Layla.”

Winning celebrity fans

Stacey quickly turned her attentions to social media as a way to expand the business’s reach, which she says has proved “effective”, particularly as it has also led to LoveLayla winning over a horde of well-known fans.

These include the likes of Dragon’s Den’s Theo Paphitis, Katie Price, and a host of reality show regulars like Georgia Toffolo, Vicky Pattison and Abbie Holborn.

Stacey says: “Celebrity fans have helped gain exposure but also grow trust behind our brand - if a celeb backs us, then we must be good!”

What comes next?

Given the business started with such small sums, Stacey is understandably delighted at having built a successful venture which has now expanded into similarly non-PC gifts like stationery, calendars and wrapping paper.

“We have never had any investment or had to remortgage the house. Our growth is financed by reinvesting back into the business.”

That latest reinvestment is in the form of a new digital printing machinery in its West Yorkshire factory, which will enable the firm to launch next-day delivery of its personalised cards and gifts.

LoveLayla has also set up an established franchise in Australia, with other markets around the world being considered.

Unsurprisingly the card business is a seasonal beast, so Stacey is optimistic that its best-ever Christmas period lies ahead, with a new range of 178 original festive cards available.

She explains: "Customer loyalty is essential to us, and we see lots of repeat business from customers who like our product range, so it's key to keep innovating and give them fresh, new ranges to look at."

And she encourages other would-be entrepreneurs to take the leap and follow their business dreams.

“Go with your gut and trust your instincts. Just give it a whirl - we launched cards because we had £30 in the bank and we needed to pay our next month’s bills, four years later we have a thriving business.”
description: Stacey Dennis was down to £30 in the bank having been made redundant, but that didn't stop her starting her greetings card business LoveLayla - named after hey young daughter
